Some basic premises in this video are false.

It has been known, for at least many decades, that beetles do use these visual features to "show off" or, in other words, to mate.

As in this tragicomic case, for example, «Male Julodimorpha bakewelli [jewel beetles] were observed attempting to copulate with beer bottles. Colour and reflection of tubercles on the bottle glass are suggested as causes for attraction and release of sexual behaviour.»:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7nStp4urqcM

http://www.earthtimes.org/nature/beetles-keeping-it-bottled-up/1440/

Also, many insects and birds have more cones in their optic system, which allows them to see more colors (infrared & ultraviolet) than most of us mammals do.  Certain species of plants and insects are painted with such "invisible" colors to attract prey (or mates) or to evade predators.  It's how some flowers trick bees and hummingbirds into spreading their pollen: As the animals brush against the plant while having a tasty drink of nectar, they unknowingly collect pollen on their bodies which is then deposited onto other receptive plants far away.

Jewel beetle: Evolve iridescence to hide from predator 😎

Depth perception gets disrupted! Left/right eye see slightly different coloring of the same thing, implying it is closer or farther than it really is!
The closer the predator gets, the stronger the parallax effect is gonna get.
The shiny bug becomes a 'fnord': sensory data so far out of left-field the brain mis-classifies it or just blanks it.
When you walk into a room and realize you don't know why you are there? You saw a fnord.
Pokemon players: Shiny beetle? Imma catch that

I used to fly large model rockets; 4-6 feet in length.
At one event, a proud Rocketeer brought an enormous rocket that he had wrapped in gold-tint mylar tape. Very shiny!
Up it flew, and was very to track in the sky.
It fell in grass only two feet tall, and was lost for days!
When it was found, it was the reflectiveness of the tape that had hidden it so well.
It was deep in the grass, reflecting the image of the grass around it.
The person who found tripped over the thing!

Modern stealthy fighter jets try very hard to be as "black" as possible to the radio waves emmitted by radar... this video got me thinking it'd probably be easier and cheaper to just cover the planes with several layers of reflecting dust in such a pattern that the return angle varies with the exact wavelength used - this would confuse radars as well, as most use low frequency first and then change into a high frequency, focused beam to lock a target
